subject: Re: [junit] Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: I hate to reply to my own relpy, but you could also look at the documents that come with JUnit ( A Cook s Tour , etc.) -- they are a great starting place.
messageBody:
I hate to reply to my own relpy, but you could also look at the
documents that come with JUnit ("A Cook's Tour", etc.) -- they are a
great starting place. There's plenty of lit. in the stores, as well as
on the web. Just look around...

=jason

On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 14:52, Jason Rogers wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-06-10 at 12:58, balakrishnan sengodan wrote:
> > With out using GET method, how do we test the method
> > that does not return value. Please give me an example.
>
> First of all, there is a wealth of knowledge to be found in the
> archives. You should try looking there before posting.
>
> A 'void' method should have some discernable effect on the system,
> right? Test the effect.
>
> public class Counter {
> .
> .
> .
> public void incrementBy(int count) {
> this.counter += count;
> }
> .
> .
> .
> }
>
> public class CounterTest extends TestCase {
> .
> .
> .
> public void testIncrementBy() {
> Counter counter = new Counter();
> assertEquals("initial value", 0, counter.getCount());
>
> counter.incrementBy(5);
> assertEquals("incremented value", 5, counter.getCount());
> }
> .
> .
> .
> }
>
> =jason
